captions.text: [CAR ENGINE ROARS]
MATT FARAH: What's up, guys?
Your boy, Matt Farah here.

Now hopefully, you are massive
fans of this show, and
watching it every week.

And if you are, you will
remember that last week we

went to Natrona Airport
for a tuner car
shoot out, half mile.

And some of you have commented,
on the video, that

I should probably try
out the winner.

Well, it turns out that entire
event was organized just for

us as an audition to
be on this show.
And ask, and ye shall receive.

So today I have brought
that very car.

Everything is so well
engineered, so perfect, that

they never feel quite as fast,
quite as far over the edge, or

quite as crazy as the
numbers imply.

Switzer Performance has one
solution, double the
horsepower.

In 2009, this GTR made
485 horsepower.

Now it makes 834
at the wheels.

This earns it a very appropriate
nickname, the
Veyron killer.
Physics need not apply.

CHRIS: You're going to get face
cramps because you're
going to be smiling so much.
[LAUGHS]

When you drive the car, you're
going to have face cramps.
Trust me.
It's pretty awesome.

MATT FARAH: Normally, when we
start filming something like

this, I drive a car a little
bit, before we start rolling,

to get a feel for it I haven't
done that because I want the
full Switzer GTR experience.
Starts right up.

Idles like a normal GTR, R, R,
R. He told me to turn traction

off because, with it on, I get
wheel spin, no matter what.
So here we go.

OK, the clutch is engaged a
little differently than the
last GTR I drove.
OK, it shifts really fast.

It's visceral, but on
very light throttle,
so far feeling GTR-ish.

If the dyno sheet is to be
believed, this will almost

certainly be the fastest car
that I've ever driven.
Oh, a straightaway.
That was only about 4,500 RPM.
This thing revs to eight.

Man, you can hear the blowoff
valves going, sounds raspy.
Fast.
OK, that was 100.

You just told me you didn't
realize what's happening.

Boost, boost, boost,
boost, boost.
[BLEEP]
me.

Chris's biggest concern with
this car is actually running

out of brakes, which is
a genuine possibility.

Usually you don't think of a GTR
as a car with not enough
braking power.

But you have 900 horsepower
at your disposal--
CHRIS: brakes--

I still have stock brake
pads on here.

So when I go up in the canyons
and, after some time, the pads

will definitely overheat, so
you have to be consciously
aware of that as well.
The suspension is bone stock.

The alignment is stock
from the factory.

The tires have been replaced
with Toyo 888s.

When you double the horsepower
in the car, honestly it
can't handle it.

And that's the honest truth,
and I'll elaborate on that.

One, you have the weakest link
on these cars is the

transmission, so Switzer
Performance procured Dodson

and Shep Transmissions
to handle that task.

But the cool part about the car
that Switzer Performance

did is, there's a low boost
for the canyons or
autocrossing.

Then you have medium boost,
depending on the
track that you're at.

Like, say Button Willow, it
would be more advantageous to

run that, instead of like, at
Willow Springs, you'd run on
high boost.

Me, personally, I'd probably run
it in medium boost because

it goes like hell
in high boost.
MATT FARAH: It shifts hard.

It shifts a lot more
like a Lamborghini
than it does a GTR.

Could be due to Switzer's
upgraded transmission
components.
That sound.

It's not like anything
I've ever heard.

It's sounds kind of like Steve
Millen's Nissan GTR did.
But it's very unique, raspy.
It's throaty.

It's kind of, dare I say,
annoying, a little bit.

I don't even know if it's
a good sound, it's
just a lot of it.

How do you get this much power
out of a six cylinder engine?

I asked myself that
earlier today.

And then Neil Switzer sent
me a build sheet.

So why don't we go through
exactly how to do that?
Switzer fuel injectors kits.

Switzer monster inner
cooler kits.
Switzer V2 turbos.

High pressure waste
gate actuators.
Cobb access port.

8900 calibration for
Cobb access port.

Mass airflow meter intake
and filter assembly.
8900 sensor upgrade package.
High flow intakes.
V2 test pipes.

Ethanol spec fuel
system upgrades.
Switzer cooling package.
Electronic boost controller.
HKS Legamax SS exhaust.
PBG first gear set.

Dodson clutch upgrade Dotson
front wheel drive retainer.

Dotson mechanical locks,
one and two.
O-ring and seal upgrade kit.

Oil pump shaft upgrade
with blueprint.
Six neodymium magnets.
High temp rear diff oil seals.

Stainless reusable
internal filter.

Switzer spec Molly pistons,
pins and rings.

Switzer spec Carrillo
connecting rods.
Switzer spec camshaft.

Switzer blueprinted engine
and oil pumps.
Switzer bearing set.
Switzer gasket set.

Labor, oil change, oil filter,
diff service, fluid and clear
[INAUDIBLE].
That makes $60,569 Wow.

The downside of driving an E85
powered car is fuel economy.

It's 30% worse, on average,
than a gas powered car.

And in California, you just
can't find the stuff, so we
brought our own fuel truck.

Because it only gets about nine
miles per gallon and you

never know when you're going
to need a refill.

A Bugatti Veyron will run a 10.2
quarter mile at about 135
miles an hour.
This thing--

But the practicality
is still here.
This is a full interior.

I've got the air conditioning
on.

I've got a good radio,
comfortable seats, lots of
leather all over everything.

CHRIS: What I love about this
car is that it's an absolute

sleeper, absolutely totally
100% sleeper.

Air conditioning, stereo, full
interior, stock wheels.
It's pretty awesome.

MATT FARAH: You run out of road
so fast, I may have to go
find myself a straightaway.
OK, ready.
I just found something out.
Chris sandbagged me.

And this whole morning, I was
not driving on full boost.

He didn't want me to get
overpowered and mess up, so he
only gave me half boost.

But now he trusts me, foolishly,
and he's given me
full boost.

So let's see what happens with
full boost, from a 40 mile an
hour roll, in second gear.
Here we go.
Oh Jesus Christ!
[CHORTLING]
Oh, my God.
Oh, my God.
The person--

the person who built this car
is completely mental.

CHRIS: What would I
want for the car?

Oh, I'm never selling
my Switzer 8900.
That's never going to happen.
No.
Not going to happen.
Sorry.

MATT FARAH: What we have here is
something very interesting.

It's a sleeper without really
being a sleeper.

Everyone knows the GTR is
fast, but no one knows,

outside of the car, how
fast this thing is.

I mean 900 horsepower is
completely insane, and the

fact that you sacrifice almost
zero practicality-- you've got
four seats.

You've got a radio, air
conditioning, automatic

transmission, all the things
you'd want, aside from, of

course, the E85 situation, which
can be fixed if you want
to spend a little more money.

Switzer has a flex fuel setup,
and you can run either pump

gas or E85 and switch on the fly
But if you have your own

fuel pump in your house,
who cares, right?

The other thing is, it's
impressive to me, a testament

to Switzer's ideals as a
company, that they're willing

to back up a 900 horsepower
upgrade
with a two year warranty.
You call them, Neil picks up.

Even though Chris is the second
owner of this car, they

still handle his maintenance and
everything he needs as if

he built the car directly
from them.

And let's not forget that before
Chris had this car, its

first owner Fahdi is widely
known for beating the crap out

of it and it still
runs like this.

So with that in mind, I'd like
to thank Chris for letting us
drive his car today.

I'd like to thank Neil and Tim
Switzer for building something
so completely insane.

And I now have a fastest
car I've ever driven.

So follow us at
thesmokeandtire.com and we

will see you next week
on Tuned, right here
on the Drive network.

comments.author: UnseenLive1

comments.text:
To all those who are calling him out on the GTR not being a sleeper, the 
man's absolutely right. A sleeper or stealth car is ANY car that has 
significantly upgraded performance that has no visual upgrades whatsoever. 
A GTR can't really be a hidden race car because one in and of itself has 
amazing street credibility, but the point is that it has twice the power of 
a stock GTR with no visual upgrades. True "junk car that drives like a 
track star" sleeper? Nope; can't do it. Sleeper by definition? Most 
definitely.﻿

comments.author: WilsonFilms

comments.text:
950 horsepower out of 6 cilinder? Maybe you guys need to realize that 
horsepower isnt everything when judging the power of a car. How fast does 
it go from 0-100 km/h? What is the top-speed? How quick can it go round 
corners? And most of all, will it be control-able at super high speeds not 
driven on a straight line? You just cant compare a car that looks like a 
3-door sedan, with a V12 ferrari or pagani. They dont even play in the same 
stadium, let alone the same ballgame. I mean like ok, can it go 370 km/h 
(pagani) or 411km/h (veyron)? :DD lol﻿
comments.author: contradoor12

comments.text:
+Daniel Garcia a gtr will never beat a ferrari on a track. A ferrari will 
always have a better lap-time. Acceleration is just 1 of many aspects to a 
car... U know that in order to have a good lap-time breaking is almost as 
important as speeding up? How about steering / handling in corners? Come 
on, the gtr is an ok car for the price, nothing more...

You're stupid af the gtr has a better lateral acceleration than an r8 and

Why'd I even bother responding to something so old and stupid in the first 
place...sigh...

comments.author: PC Master Race

comments.text:
+Stephen Bagnell you are at the pump in this GTR, then a man driving an 
Aventador (not exactly the most realistic situation) then he asks to race, 
you ask to put $20 on the race, the Lambo driver accepts assuming your car 
is under powered because it looks stock, you go on the highway and blow him 
out of the water because this GTR has 200hp more and most likely less 
weight, he wasnt expected to get thrashed there for it is a sleeper, not 
quite 850hp Turbo 5.0 Ford LTD with a wheelchair on the back kind of 
sleeper but still

comments.text:
+Vladimir Yuri The track close by to my house. He has a point. Its fast 
(I'm saying that because I'm sure the hate is coming) but its a boring car 
to drive. Same as any automatic car. Would drive it for a bit for fun but 
I'm going back to the Ferrari and Corvette at the end of the day. Not my 
kind of car I guess, wouldn't sell my soul to an automatic for 2.9 seconds 
and no prestige. Bring on the butthurt.

comments.text:
The GT-R is a brilliant, advanced work of art... But I think that Nissan 
should have continued the RB26DETT motor and tranny with larger turbos, 
stroked, and use a lighter chassis. . But Japanese manufacturers are 
geniuses and understand how to make reliable cars that can keep up with 
exotics , if not outperform them...﻿
